metadata.title: High Electrochemical Stability of 3D Cross-linked Network PEO@nano-SiO2 Composite Polymer Electrolyte for Lithium Metal Batteries†

ARTICLE

High Electrochemical Stability of 3D Cross-linked Network
PEO@nano-SiO2 Composite Polymer Electrolyte for Lithium Metal
Batteries†
Yinghua Zhu,a,b Jiang Cao, *a,d Hong Chen,b,c Qipeng Yu,a and Baohua Li,*a
Polymer electrolytes have attracted great attentions due to their promising abilities, however, only further improving their safety and electrochemical performance can make them to be used as the next generation electrolyte. Here, a novel composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) with nano-SiO2 acted as cross-linking agents to form an 3D cross-linked network was synthesized to improve the electrochemical stability and mechanical ability. The novel CPE exhibited some excellent properties such as high ionic conductivity (4.65×10-3 S cm-1 at room temperature) with broad electrochemical stability window (~5.4 V vs. Li/Li+), high ionic transfer number (0.45), high mechanical robustness and flexibility (Young’s module ~8.9 MPa, breaking strain 181%), and excellent interface stability. The lithium metal battery LiFePO4/CPE/Li was assembled and delivered specific capacities of 160 mA h g-1 with capacity retention of above 90% after 500 cycles at 1C. Furthermore, to cooperate with high voltage cathode materials LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4, the novel CPE still delivered superior cycling performance than traditional electrolyte.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
The increasing energy demands drives the development of high-energy density batteries. Lithium ion battery (LIBs) has been widely employed, but current energy density is far from meeting the demand.1-5 Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) have been regarded as the next generation technologies, due to the highest theoretical specific capacity (3870 mA h g-1) and lowest redox potential (-3.04 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode) of lithium metal anodes.6 Furthermore, lithium metal anodes are lithium ion resource, which can cooperate with none-lithium ion cathodes for next generation energy storage systems such as Liair and Li-S batteries.7 However, there are several severe problems of LMBs. The first is how to restrain the uncontrolled growth of lithium (Li) dendrites, which are mainly induced by nonuniform charge deposition and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer formed on the lithium metal anodes during the Li deposition process leading to short cycle life or even stabbing separator.8 Secondly, Lithium metal anodes will
react with liquid electrolyte to generate unstable SEI, which is fragile, and would break and rebuild along with the process of lithium plating and striping, consuming lithium and resulting in “dead” Li, reducing the battery capacity.9, 10 Moreover, Li metal electrode cooperates with high potential cathode will greatly increase the energy density of the entire battery. But it brings great demands for high voltage stability of electrolyte, conventional electrolyte is hard to tolerate the high potential and caused the decomposition of electrolyte.
To solve these problems, plenty efforts have been done.
Such as the structural design of current collector,11, 12 surface modification of Li and artificial-SEI,13-15 electrolyte additives16 and solid-state electrolytes.17, 18 Most of them aim to achieve uniform charge deposition and change the growth direction of dendrite. Solid state electrolyte attracted the most attention among them, due to its excellent lithium dendrite inhibition ability and safety. But there are still many problems hard to solve for all solid electrolytes, ceramic electrolytes are difficult to close contact with electrode, which caused large interphase resistance, solid polymer electrolytes usually have too low room-temperature ionic conductivity for practical application.19,20 Solid-liquid composite electrolyte and gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) are more practical. Gel polymer electrolyte (GPE) has been widely studied for its high room temperature ionic conductivity and perfect interphase contact ability.21-23
Poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO) has a good affinity to lithium salts and electrochemical stability against lithium, but when

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
PEO is used as polymer matrix of GPE, it exhibits poor mechanical properties.24 On account of that, usually some hard polymer (like poly(styrene) (PS)) are introduced to form block copolymer.25 Obviously, non-conductivity polymer PS will decrease the overall bulk conductivity of GPE, it is hard to balance the mechanical property and ionic conductivity. Composite polymer electrolyte (CPE) containing liquid electrolyte and polymer matrix which reinforced by nanoparticle filler can achieve good mechanical property and other wonderful electrochemical performance, such as higher ionic conductivity, lower interface impedance, wider electrochemical stability window, and so on.26, 27 Uniform dispersing nanoparticle fillers in polymer matrix is the precondition of reinforcement.28, 29 Owing to the strong specific surface energy of nanoparticles, fillers are easy to aggregate together by van der Waals force. Particles agglomeration generate defects leading to poor mechanical property and impeding the fast transport of Li+.30 Several strategies have been employed to restrain the agglomeration, including surface modification and in situ synthesis, to improve the mechanical property and electrochemical performance.27, 31 Linear PEO is easy to crystallize, which obstructs the practical application. To solve these problems, disrupting the regularity of PEO segments or increasing the amount of branched chains could reduce the crystallization of PEO, and introducing cross-linking agents could form more tight structure.32, 33 In our group’s previous work,34 a novel 3D-crosslinked network gel polymer electrolyte (3D-GPE) based on PEO was prepared by initiator-free one-pot synthesis strategy based on a ring-opening polymerization reaction. The 3D-GPE exhibits an unprecedented combination of mechanical strength, ionic conductivity, and effective suppression of Li dendrite growth. In this study, to further increase electrochemical stability window and mechanical ability of the 3D-GPE, a novel 3D-crosslined gel composite polymer electrolyte (3D-GCPE) was prepared successfully by above mentioned process. The structure and properties of the 3D-GCPE were investigated, and this 3D-GCPE exhibits improved physical and electrochemical properties so that it can be used in high voltage Li-metal batteries.

sections.heading: Materials
sections.text:
Silica (SiO2, average 15nm) purchase from Aladdin
company. 3-Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxy silane (γ-GPS, 97%), poly (ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDE, average Mn = 500), diamino-poly (propylene glycol) (DPPG, average), poly (vinylidene fluoride-cohexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP), Dimethyl Formamide (DMF) were purchase from Aldrich. The liquid electrolyte (1M LiPF6 in EC/DMC/DEC 1:1:1 v/v) purchase from Shanshan technology. Commercial PP separators (Celgard 2400) were purchase from Celgard company, Commercial carbon-coated LiFePO4 was purchase from Shenzhen Dynanonic Co., Ltd (average particle size: 0.2 μm; carbon content: 2 wt%), Commercial LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 was purchase from Hunan Changyuan Lico Co., Ltd. Commercial LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 was purchase from Hefei Kejing Materials Technology Co., Ltd.
Surface grafting of SiO2
3-Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxysilane grafted nano-silica(γ-GPS-gSiO2) were prepared as follow: First 300mg SiO2 were dispersed in a mixture of 90 ml ethanol and 10 ml DI water by ultrasonication, followed by the addition of 30 mg γ-GPS. Under vigorous stirring, adjusting the pH of solution to 4 by oxalic acid. The solution was kept vigorous stirring for 4 h at 75 °C. After that grafted SiO2 were collected by centrifugation, then washed several times using mixture solution of DI water and ethanol, and finally the product was drying overnight at 60 °C.

sections.heading: Preparation of 3D-GCPE/SiO2-GPE/GPE membrane
sections.text:
The 3D-GCPE was prepared by one-pot synthesis strategy.
First, a certain amount of PVDF-HFP (20% of total mass) was completely dissolved in DMF by magnetic string at room temperature. Then, proportional dried γ-GPS-g-SiO2 was added into the mixture solution and well dispersed by ultrasonication. Then 0.3 g PEGDA and 0.7 g DPPO were added into above mixture solution and the solution was keep stirring 6h to get a homogeneous solution. Subsequently, the solution was poured on a Teflon plate and heated at 8 °C for 24 h to evaporate DMF and make all epoxy groups were reacted. Finally, the resultant membranes were obtained after cooling to room temperature and were washed with ethanol for three times to remove the unreacted monomer, and then dried under vacuum for 12 h at 60°C. SiO2-GPE was prepared by the same strategy with replace γ-GPS-g-SiO2 with pure SiO2. And GPE was prepared without inorganic fillers. Membranes were immersed in liquid electrolyte (1 M LiPF6 in EC/DMC/DEC=1/1/1, v/v) for 24 h in argon-filled glove box, and using filter paper to absorb the excess solution on the surface of membrane before assembling the cell.

sections.heading: Characterization
sections.text:
Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR, Nicolet IS
50) was used to record the IR spectra of the samples in the range of 400 – 4000 cm-1. The morphology and microstructure of samples are probed using field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM, HITACHI SU8010). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a D8 Advance diffractometer at a scan rate of 10° min-1 from 10° to 70°. The TGA（TGA2） measurements were performed in a temperature range from room temperature to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a nitrogen atmosphere. The mechanical performance of samples was measured from stress-stain tests using CMT6104 instrument (MTS industrial systems corporation) with a tensile speed of 10 mm min−1.

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The ionic conductivity was measured in the frequency
range from 1 MHz to 100 mHz by ac impedance spectroscopy

using VMP3 multichannel electrochemical station (Biologic Science Instruments, France), with the cell configuration of SS/electrolyte/SS (stainless steel) and test temperature from 5 °C to 85 °C. The ionic conductivity was calculated according to the following eqn. (1):

where L, S, and R stand for the membrane thickness, the
membrane area, and the ohmic resistance, respectively.
Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was
measured in the frequency range from 100kHz to 0.01Hz using VMP3 multichannel electrochemical station. For studying the ionic transference number (tLi+) of electrolyte, EIS analysis was performed before and after chronoamperometry (CA),During CA a polarization voltage of 10mv was applied for 6,000 s until a steady state was reached. tLi+ was calculated using following eqn. (2)
tLi+ = 𝐼𝑠(∆𝑉 − 𝐼0𝑅0)

Where ∆𝑉 is the constant voltage applied to the cell, 𝐼0
and 𝐼𝑠 represent the initial and steady-state currents, and R0 and Rs are the initial and steady-state resistances of the passivating on Li electrode, respectively.
To evaluate the electrochemical stability of electrolyte,
cyclic voltammograms (CV) was carried out with the cell configuration of Li/electrolyte/SS. The CV was implemented at room temperature from -0.5 V to 6 V (versus Li+/Li) at a scan rate of 1mV s-1 on VMP3 multichannel electrochemical station.
The galvanostatic lithium plating and striping test was perform on a Land battery test system (CT 2001, Wuhan Land Electronic Co. Ltd., China) at 25 °C with the cell configuration of Li/electrolyte/Li. LiFePO4 based cathode was prepared by pasting a mixture of active material, carbon black (super-P), and PVDF at a weight rate of 80:10:10 on Al foil. LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 and LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 based cathode was prepared by the same progress. Cycling and rate performance of cells with different electrolytes were measured on Land battery test system at 25 °C.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
Scheme 1 shows the synthesis procedure of
inorganic/organic composite polymer network. First, 3- Glycidoxypropyltrimethoxy silane (γ-GPS) was grafted on the surface of nano-silica with 15 nm average size by the hydrolysiscondensation reaction, the R-Si-O-R was hydrolyzed in an acid environment and then quickly reacted with -OH on the surface of nano-silica to form Si-O-Si-R. In addition, hydrolyzed γ-GPS would react each other, made more γ-GPS grafted on the
surface of nano-silica. Then, the product γ-GPS grafted SiO2 (γGPS-g-SiO2), poly (ethylene glycol) diglycidyl ether (PEGDE), and diamino-poly (propylene glycol) (DPPG) were crosslinking by ring-open reaction to form an inorganic/organic composite polymer network, in addition, 20 wt% Polyvinylidene fluoridehexafluoropropylene (PVDF-HFP) was added to improve filmforming ability. After that, the obtained membrane absorbed liquid electrolyte to form 3D-crosslined gel composite polymer electrolyte (3D-GCPE).
To successfully build this inorganic/organic composite
polymer network, the agglomeration of nano-particle, which was arisen from the large surface energies of nanoparticles, need to be dealt with at first. Furthermore, there were many - OH groups on the surface of nano-silica leading to poor lipophilicity, and were hard to be uniformly dispersed in organic solutions.35 Introducing organic molecule graft on nano-silica is helpful to solve those problems and obtain lower surface energies and better lipophilicity. In this research, γ-GPS was introduced and acted as grafting molecule which contains an epoxy group terminal that can react with DPPG. So, this grafting poly-γ-GPS could combine inorganic SiO2 and PEO backbone by chemical bones to build an inorganic/organic composite polymer network. As shown in Fig. 1a, b, there are a few nanometers thick of polymer layer grafted on the surface of silica and exhibited a star feature. The grafted poly-γ-GPS contains epoxy group, which can react with amino group of DPPG, so that nano-silica can act as crosslinking agents, and it will be embed in the polymer matrix by chemical bonding to form a tighter network.
Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) of γ-GPS,
γ-GPS-g-SiO2 and 3D-GCPE4 (contain different amount of γ-GPSg-SiO2 named as 3D-GCPE2, 3D-GCPE4, 3D-GCPE6, 3D-GCPE8 and 3D-GCPE10, from 2 mass percent to 10 mass percent) is shown in Fig. 1c. It can be seen that absorption peaks at 2960 cm-1, 2870 cm-1and 1460 cm-1, which represent the symmetrical and asymmetrical stretching vibration and bending vibration of -CH2 group, presented at the curve of γ-GPS-g-SiO2. Moreover, the peak at 1050 cm-1 of blue curve which was assigned to the stretching vibration of Si-O-C group was shifted to 1100 cm-1 for the curve of γ-GPS-g-SiO2 indicating the formation of Si-O-Si group. Combining the results of TEM, all these proofs proved that γ-GPS was successfully grafted on the surface of nano-SiO2. In addition, the peak at 910 cm-1 of blue curve is the absorption peak of epoxy group, which was disappeared in the curve of 3DGCPE4, and appearing the C-N absorption peak at 930 cm-1, proving that the crosslinking reactions between epoxy group of γ-GPS and amino group of DPPG were happened. So, SiO2 and polymer backbone are successfully connected through using γGPS as bridge, and formed an inorganic/organic composite polymer network. Fig.1d shows the photograph of 3D-GCPE4. which is flexible and smooth with thickness of around 100 um.

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
4 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
To investigate whether γ-GPS-g-SiO2 was uniformly
dispersed in organic solution and formed uniform network. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was conducted on obtained electrolyte membrane. Fig. 2a and b are SEM images of membrane prepared by directly mixing primary nano-SiO2 into polymer (SiO2-GPE), in which the heterogeneous structure caused by inhomogeneous distribution and aggregation of nano-SiO2 could be found. Due to the fact that γ-GPS-g-SiO2 has better lipophilicity and could react with polymer monomer, 3DGCPE formed a homogeneous and tight inorganic/polymer composite network, and a uniform wrinkly morphology was shown in Fig. 2c, d. The wrinkly morphology also indicated the excellent electrolyte-uptake ability of membrane.28
Polyethylene oxide (PEO) is a commonly used polymer
matrix for gel polymer electrolyte, because of the oxygen on ethylene oxide (EO) chains has strong electron donating characteristic, which can facilitate dissociation of lithium salt. And PEO chain segments have excellent flexibility which are beneficial to the transport of Li+. But PEO has high degree of crystallinity hindering the movement of chains segments and the ability of absorbing electrolyte.36, 37 X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of linear PEO, 3D-GPE membrane, and composite membranes which contain different amount of γ-GPS-g-SiO2 are shown in Fig. 3a. Several sharp diffraction peaks of linear PEO indicated the high crystallinity. On the contrary, no sharp diffraction peaks excepting a broad peak is observed from 3DGPE, 3D-GCPE2, 3D-GCPE4, 3D-GCPE6, 3D-GCPE8 and 3DGCPE10. This is owing to the built 3D-network structure extremely decreases the crystallization of PEO.
Mechanical property is an important aspect for the
application of gel polymer electrolyte membrane. Good toughness of membrane can suppress dendrite growth and avoid penetration.17 Good flexibility of membrane can accommodate the expansion of electrode materials and fit to the roll-to-roll LMBs assembly process.38 Incorporating inorganic nanofillers in polymer matrix is an effective approach to improve the mechanical property of GPE. But it is hard to be improved if the inorganic nanofillers could not be dispersed homogenously in polymer matrix. On the contrary, agglomeration of fillers may decrease its flexibility greatly. Nanofillers acted as cross-linking agents reacted with polymer monomer to form a 3D-network could improve the toughness and preserve the flexibility of membrane at the same time. The stress-strain test exhibit that 3D-GCPE4 has the highest tensile strength of 8.95 MPa with breaking strain reaching to 181.9 % (Fig. 3b). 4%-SiO2-GPE is the membrane made by directly mixing 4 wt% primary nano-SiO2 into polymer, its tensile strength slightly increased comparing to 3D-GPE, but the breaking strain fell precipitously. For 3D-GCPE2 and 3D-GCPE8, the performance is relatively poor maybe due to those deficient or excessive cross-linking agents.
The surface of nano-SiO2 usually has a lot of -OH groups,
which can act as Lewis-acid competing with lithium salt cations, providing more free Li+.30, 39, 40 Even if our nano-SiO2 surface were grafted with polymer, there are still a lot of -OH groups exist on the surface, that can be found from the FTIR test, a broad absorption peak around 3400 cm-1 (red curve of Fig. 1c). Moreover, γ-GPS-SiO2 acted as cross-linking agents enhanced the strength of network, and improved the flexibility of network as well, because the Si-O-C bonds are more flexible than the CO-C bones in the PEG molecule chains. It would make chain segments movement easier and favor the transport of Li+.34 Fig.3c shows the ionic conductivity of 3D-GCPE with added different amount of γ-GPS-g-SiO2 from 0 wt% to 10 wt% at 25 °C. 3D-GCPE4 exhibited the highest ionic conductivity value (4.65×10-3 S cm-1), which is also the better mechanical property shown in Fig. 3b. This is attributed to the two functions mentioned above that γ-GPS-SiO2 can provide more ‘free Li+’ and enhance the mobility of chains. Low ionic conductivity of 3D-GCPE8 and 3D-GCPE10 may result from the agglomeration of nanofillers impeding the Li+ transport pathways. Primary SiO2 cannot improve the flexibility of PEG chains, so the 4%-SiO2-GPE exhibited a lower ionic conductivity. These results are corresponded with electrolyte uptake ability tests (Supporting information table S1), 3D-GCPE4 has a high electrolyte uptake of up to 340%, which is much higher than that of ceramic-free 3D-GPE. the better absorbing ability could be attributed to the formed novel inorganic/organic composite polymer network. Fig. 3d illustrates the temperature dependence of ionic conductivity. Compared with the ceramic-free 3D-GPE, significant improvement in ionic conductivity can be observed by adding SiO2 in PEO to form GCPE, which is consistent with previously reported results.40 Obviously, by adding grafted-SiO2 the ionic conductive of GCPE was further improved, because the more flexible Si-O-C bones are easily moving at low temperature. Ionic conductivity of 3D-GCPE4 is almost 6 times higher than PP + liquid electrolyte. So, 3D-GCPE4 was chosen for next battery tests due to its best mechanical property and ionic conductivity.
To increase the energy density of the battery, many high
potential cathode materials have been developed. But most conventional electrolytes are difficult to match the high voltage cathode.40 By synthesizing the inorganic/polymer composite network, a gel composite polymer electrolyte with excellent electrochemical stability was obtained. Fig. 4a illustrated the result of Cyclic voltammograms of 3D-GPE, PP + liquid
electrolyte and 3D-GCPE4 from -0.5 V to 6 V at 25 ℃. For 3D-
GPE, it has an obvious decomposition peak at a potential around 4.2 V versus vs. Li+/Li, which was even lower than PP + Liquid electrolyte (4.5 V vs. Li+/Li). Obviously, 3D-GCPE4 has excellent electrochemical stability that distinct decomposes did not appear until 5.4 V. Apart from the decomposition of the polymer itself at high voltage, previous work41 found that the anodic decomposition of anion can be responsible for the

sections.heading: Journal Name ARTICLE
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 5
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
electrochemical instability at high voltage. The clear mechanism of electrolyte to endure anodic decomposition at high potential versus Li+/Li remains elusive, but applying some methods to limit anions approaching cathode may help.42 So, the high oxidation potential of 3D-GCPE4 maybe owing to the Lewis-acid effect of SiO2, which can absorb anions to inhibit its deposition at cathode side in some extent, and the novel inorganic/polymer composite network also has better oxidation resistance.
Low ionic transfer number (tLi+) will result in a larger
electric field across the Li/electrolyte interface which will lead to the decomposition of electrolyte and accelerate Li dendrite nucleation.43 Steady current method is used to test tLi+, Fig. 4b showed the current-time plots and Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) tests before (solid circle) and after (hollow circle) 10 mV potential polarization. Calculated tLi+ of 3D-GCPE4 reached up to 0.45, which was much higher than tLi+ of liquid electrolyte (0.22). This may be attributed to the function of γGPS-SiO2 which promoted the dissociation of lithium salts, moreover, the polymer matrix of 3D-GCPE can hinder the transport of PF- 6 anions as well.
A polarization test of the Li/Li symmetric cells assembled
with the 3D-GCPE4 and liquid electrolyte absorbed in commercial PP separator was performed to investigate the dynamical stability of the Li/electrolyte interface. The Li/Li symmetric cells were charged and discharged for 3 h during each process with current density 0.25 mA cm-2, as shown in Fig. 4c. The cell with 3D-GCPE4 can stably circle more than 1600 h with a gradually reduce polarization voltage at the current density of 0.25 mA cm-2, while the cell with PP + liquid electrolyte exhibit a large and irreversible voltage drop around at the 400 h under the same condition, which is attributed to cell failure by dendrite-induced short circuits.34 This result suggested that highly stable lithium plating/stripping cycling was achieved in this 3D-GCPE4 and that the Li dendrite growth has been significantly restrained.21, 44 To further analyse the behavior of lithium deposition/stripping, the polarization test of both cells at a larger current density of 1 mA cm−2 has been also examined (Fig. 4d). The cell with 3D-GCPE4 showed a small and stable polarization up to 500 h, but the cell with liquid electrolyte has a large polarization that rose sharply with cycling time increased and the voltage of cell suddenly dropped at around 360 h. This result demonstrated that the 3D-GCPE4 has good compatibility with Li metal electrode which can be used as a polymer electrolyte for Li metal batteries.
To investigate the cell performance of 3D-GCPE4, the
LiFePO4/Li cell with different electrolyte were adopted to analyse the cycling and rate performance (Fig. 5a and b). The initial discharge capacity of cells with different electrolytes containing 3D-GCPE4, 3D-GPE, 4%-SiO2-GPE and PP + liquid electrolyte are all reached 160 mA h g-1 at 0.1 C. The capacity of the cell with PP + liquid electrolyte dropped fast to 75 mA h g-1
after 340 cycles at 1 C. On the contrary, the cell with 3D-GCPE4 and 3D-GPE4 exhibit similar excellent cycling performance, which retains above 90% capacity after 500 cycles at 1 C. The cell with 4%-SiO2-PEG exhibited a poor cycling performance, which may be attributed to the unevenly distributed nanoSiO2.45 The cell with 3D-GCPE4 exhibited a good rate performance, the discharge capacity remained 124 mA h g-1 at 10 C, which was much better than the rate performance of the cell with 3D-GPE, 4 % SiO2 and PP + liquid electrolyte, as shown in Fig. 5b. This is attributed to the high ionic conductivity and improved interfacial stability of 3D-GCPE4.31, 41 Fig. 5c and Fig. S1 showed the interfacial stability after different cycles and aging time. After charging/discharging for 200 cycles, The EIS of cell with 3D-GCPE4 showed lower interfacial resistance than that of with PP + liquid electrolyte. The lower and gradually reduced interfacial resistance after aging under different time indicated that 3D-GCPE4 was stable to contact with lithium metal electrode and has an excellent interfacial compatibility. Furthermore, the overpotential value of the cell with 3D-GCPE4 was much lower than that of the cell with PP + liquid electrolyte in the cycling test. (Capacity-voltage curves in Fig. 5d, e). Upon disassembling the cells after 200 cycles at 1 C, the surface of Li metal with electrolyte used PP + liquid electrolyte showed striking cracks and pulverization. On the contrary, the surface of Li metal with electrolyte used 3D-GCPE4 exhibited smooth morphology, even if there were some voids upon, the surface of lithium was still compact. (Fig. 6)
To improve the energy density of battery, employing high
voltage and high energy cathode materials is an effective way. 3D-GCPE4 was further evaluated by assembling a full cell using LiNi0.8Co0.1Mn0.1O2 (NCM811) as cathode and lithium metal as anode. The charging and discharging cut-off voltage was set from 3.0 V to 4.5 V. The cycling performance showed in Fig. 7a. Due to the narrow oxidation window of 3D-GPE and 4%-SiO2GPE, their capacity rapidly decayed, which only remained 102.3 mA h g-1 and 69.1 mA h g-1, respectively, after 100 cycles at 1 C. On the contrary, the cell with 3D-GCPE4 displayed an improved cycling performance with slightly capacity loss (remained 136.6 mA h g-1), which is also better than the cycling performance of the cell with PP + liquid electrolyte (108.5 mA h g-1).
To further investigate the high voltage performance of 3D-
GCPE, 5V-class cathode material LiNi0.5Mn1.5O4 (LNMO) was used to cooperated with lithium metal anode to charge and discharge from 3.5 V to 4.9 V at 25 °C. Fig. 7b shows the cycling performance of cells with different electrolytes containing PP + liquid electrolyte, 4%-SiO2-GPE and 3D-GCPE4. The conventional liquid electrolyte begins to decompose at 4.5 V, which is hard to cooperate with LNMO cathode well. The capacity of the cell with 4%-SiO2-GPE decayed rapidly after 20 cycles. Due to the wide electrochemical window and the ability to absorb anions, which can inhibit their decomposition in some extent of 3D-GCPE, the cell with it exhibited a relatively stable

cycling performance compared to that with PP + liquid electrolyte. Fig. S2 is the charging and discharging curves of the Li/3D-GPE/LNMO at initial several cycles. The first charging curve of the cell is unstable and the capacity is much higher than actual capacity of the electrode. This may attribute to the drastic decomposition of pure PEO matrix at high voltage. That causes the cell failed to cycle normally at subsequent cycling.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In summary, A novel 3D cross-linked network PEO@nanoSiO2 composite polymer electrolyte was successfully synthesized by initiator-free one-pot synthesis strategy on a ring-opening polymerization reaction. Grafted nano-SiO2 acted as cross-linking agents and fillers to enhance the strength and flexibility of polymer network, which made the novel 3D-GCPE exhibited excellent electrochemical stability. With a small amount of γ-GPS grafted nano-SiO2 introduced, the electrochemical window of 3D-GCPE4 was widened to 5.4 V with higher tLi+. When the 3D-GCPE4 was cooperated with LiFePO4, the cells delivered excellent cycling performance, more importantly, when it was cooperated with 4.5 V high-voltage cathode NCM811 and 4.9 V high-voltage cathode LNMO, it can also exhibit stable performance. In addition, this polymer electrolyte may get better high voltage cycling performance, if carbonic ester is replaced with ionic liquid. This work provides an advance strategy to improve the electrochemical stability of polymer electrolytes and facilitate the progress of high-voltage electrolytes.

sections.text: There are no conflicts to declare.
